API Authentication Guide

Overview

This guide covers all authentication methods supported by our API.

Authentication Methods

We support multiple authentication approaches to fit different use cases.

API Key Authentication

The simplest method for server-to-server communication.

Implementation Examples
  • JavaScript
    
const apiKey = 'your-api-key';
fetch('/api/data', {
    headers: {
        'Authorization': `Bearer ${apiKey}`
    }
});
  • Python
    
import requests

headers = {'Authorization': 'Bearer your-api-key'}
response = requests.get('/api/data', headers=headers)
  • cURL
    
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer your-api-key" \
     https://api.example.com/data

OAuth 2.0 Authentication

For applications that need to act on behalf of users.

Supported Flows
Authorization Code Flow

Recommended for server-side applications with a backend.

  1. Redirect to Authorization Server

    Send user to the authorization endpoint with required parameters.

    • Required Parameters
      • client_id: Your application's client ID
      • response_type: Set to "code"
      • redirect_uri: Where to send the user after authorization
      • scope: Requested permissions
  2. Handle Authorization Response

    Process the authorization code returned to your redirect URI.

  3. Exchange Code for Token

    Make a server-side request to exchange the code for an access token.

  • Security Considerations

    Always validate the state parameter to prevent CSRF attacks.

    • PKCE (Proof Key for Code Exchange)

      Recommended for mobile and SPA applications.

    • Token Storage

      Store access tokens securely and never expose them in client-side code.

JWT Token Format

Our API uses JSON Web Tokens for secure information transmission.

Token Structure

Header

Contains the token type and signing algorithm.

Payload

Contains the claims (user info, permissions, expiration).

Signature

Ensures the token hasn't been tampered with.

Standard Claims

Required Claims
iss (Issuer)

Identifies the principal that issued the JWT.

exp (Expiration Time)

Timestamp when the token expires.

iat (Issued At)

Timestamp when the token was issued.

Custom Claims

user_id

Unique identifier for the authenticated user.

permissions

Array of permission strings granted to the user.

Error Handling

Authentication Errors

401 Unauthorized

Invalid or missing authentication credentials.

403 Forbidden

Valid credentials but insufficient permissions.

429 Too Many Requests

Rate limit exceeded for the current time window.

Related Documentation

Rate Limiting

API requests are subject to rate limiting to ensure fair usage.

Rate Limit Headers

Response headers provide information about current rate limit status.

  • X-RateLimit-Limit

    The maximum number of requests allowed in the time window.

  • X-RateLimit-Remaining

    The number of requests remaining in the current window.

  • X-RateLimit-Reset

    Timestamp when the rate limit window resets.

Best Practices

Token Management

Implement proper token lifecycle management.

Refresh Tokens

Use refresh tokens to maintain long-term access without re-authentication.

Token Rotation

Regularly rotate API keys and refresh tokens for enhanced security.

Testing Authentication

Sandbox Environment

Use our sandbox API for testing without affecting production data.

Recommended Tools
  1. Postman

    Popular API testing tool with OAuth 2.0 support.

  2. curl

    Command-line tool for making HTTP requests.
